column1: Ferdinand Friedrich Georg Ludwig Freiherr von Wrangel (Russian: Фердина́нд Петро́вич Вра́нгель
column2: tr. Ferdinand Petrovich Vrangel'; 9 January 1797 [O.S. 29 December 1796] – 6 June [O.S. 25 May] 1870) was a Baltic German explorer and seaman in the Imperial Russian Navy
column3: Honorable Member of the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences
column4: a founder of the Russian Geographic Society. He is best known as chief manager of the Russian-American Company
column5: in fact governor of the Russian settlements in present-day Alaska.

column2: Wrangel is sometimes spelled Vrangel
column4: which more closely represents its pronunciation in German

column2: into the noble Baltic German Wrangel family and was a distant nephew of Generalfeldmarschall Friedrich von Wrangel. He graduated from the Naval Cadets College in 1815. He participated in Vasily Golovnin's world cruise on the ship Kamchatka in 1817–1819.

column1: He was appointed in 1820 to command the Kolymskaya expedition to explore the Russian polar seas. Sailing from St. Petersburg
column2: he arrived at Nizhnekolymsk on 2 November 1820
column3: and early in 1821 journeyed to Cape Shelagskiy on sledges drawn by dogs. He sailed afterward up Kolyma River
column4: advancing about 125 miles into the interior
column5: through territory inhabited by the Yakuts. On 10 March 1822
column7: and traveled 46 days on the ice
column8: reaching 72° 2' north latitude. He left Nizhnekolymsk on 1 November 1823
column9: and returned to St. Petersburg on 15 August 1824.He established that north of the Kolyma River and Cape Shelagsky there was an open sea
column11: as people thought. Together with Fyodor Matyushkin and P. Kuzmin
column12: Wrangel described the Siberian coastline from the Indigirka River to the Kolyuchinskaya Bay in the Chukchi Sea. (See Northeast Passage.) His expedition made a valuable research in glaciology
column14: and climatology and also collected data about natural resources and native population of that remote area.

column2: Wrangel led the Russian world voyage on the ship Krotky in 1825–1827.

column1: He was appointed chief manager of the Russian-American Company in 1829
column2: effectively governor of its settlements in North America (present day Alaska).  Wrangel was the first of a series of bachelor appointees to the office of governor who had to find a wife before assuming the duties in America
column3: the Russian American Company rules having been changed in 1829. Prior to his departure for Russia's American colonies
column4: he was married to Elisabeth Theodora Natalie Karoline de Rossillon
column5: daughter of Baron Wilhelm de Rossillon.

column1: He traveled to his post early in 1829
column2: by way of Siberia and Kamchatka. After thoroughly reforming the administration
column3: he introduced the cultivation of the potato
column4: opened and regulated the working of several mines
column5: and urged upon the home government the organization of a fur company. He promoted investment
column6: and sent out missionaries. He began a survey of the country
column8: built bridges and government buildings. He made geographical and ethnographical observations
column9: which he embodied in a memoir to the navy department. Recalled in 1834
column10: he returned by way of the Isthmus of Panama and the United States

column1: Wrangel was promoted to rear admiral in 1837
column2: and made director of the ship-timber department in the navy office
column3: which he held for twelve years. He became vice-admiral in 1847
column5: and temporarily severed his connection with the navy to assume the presidency of the newly reorganized Russian-American Company. Wrangel had been a member of the board of directors of the Russian-American Company from 1840 to 1849.In 1854 he re-entered active service and was made chief director of the hydrographical department of the navy. He was the Minister of the Navy 1855–1857.

column1: Wrangel retired in 1864. He opposed the sale of Alaska to the United States in 1867. Wrangel wrote the book Journey along the northern coastline of Siberia and the Arctic Ocean and other books about the peoples of northwestern America.
He lived in his last years in Ruil (Roela in Estonian) in the eastern part of Estonia. He had bought the manor in 1840. He died in Dorpat
column2: Livonia.

column17: 1841). The book influenced Charles Darwin's thinking on animal navigation
column18: leading him to propose that humans and animals possess an innate ability for dead reckoning. Darwin wrote:

column1: With regard to the question of the means by which animals find their way home from a long distance

column6: whilst passing for a long distance through hummocky ice
column8: and with no guide in the heavens or on the frozen sea. He states (but I quote only from memory of many years standing) that he
column11: failed to do that which these savages easily effected. Yet no one will suppose that they possessed any special sense which is quite absent in us. We must bear in mind that neither a compass
column14: suffices to guide a man to a particular spot through an intricate country
